entries.title: Goto
entries.description: Jump to a specific line in your code.
entries.det_desc: Goto is used to jump to a specific line during runtime. With goto, loops can easily be implemented as seen in the following examples.

examples.title: Infinite loop
examples.description: This loop will infinitely increase i by one (until an overflow-error occurs)

examples.title: Finite loop
examples.code:
i = 0
if i < 10 goto 3 end goto 4
i++ goto 2
examples.description: For each iteration this loop compares if i is smaller than 10 and increases i by one if this is the case.

entries.title: If
entries.description: Execute a block of code if expression is fulfilled.
entries.det_desc: An if clause is used to create more complex programs by introducing conditions. If a certain thing is given, then the program should do something - otherwise it shouldn't.

examples.title: Finite loop
examples.code:
i = 0
if i < 10 goto 3 end goto 4
i++ goto 2
examples.description: For each iteration this loop compares if i is smaller than 10 and increases i by one if this is the case - i won't be increased above 10.

entries.title: If else
entries.description: Execute a block of code if expression is fulfilled, otherwise execute something else.
entries.det_desc: Adding to the standard if clause, the 'else' keyword adds another layer of customization to conditions.

examples.code:
thirsty = "true"
if thirsty == "true" then milk = "existent" else milk = "gone" end
examples.description: If thirsty is set to true, then set another field called milk to existent, otherwise to gone.

entries.title: ChipWait
entries.description: Wait a given amount of time when this field is set to something other than '0'.
entries.det_desc: In order to temporarily or permanently pause the execution of your YOLOL-chip you can use this field. Positive numbers will be treated as seconds in which the chip will remain paused, negative numbers will permanently stop the execution of that chip.

examples.description: The local variable 'hello' will only be set after the 5 seconds of chip-timeout.

entries.title: Math operators
entries.det_desc:
It's math, baby!
If you've never seen operators like `+=` worry not, the following examples should clear up most things.

examples.description: The local variable 'result' will be assigned the result of given addition - in this case 10. Analog for `-`, `*`, `/`, `%`.

The local variable 'result' will first be set to 10 like above. Then `5` will be added onto the variable, resulting in 15. In short: The operation is immediately applied with a given number. Analog for `-=`, `*=`, `/=`, `%=`.

entries.title: String operators
entries.det_desc:
Adding or removing something to/from a String. If you've never seen operators like `+=` worry not, the following examples should clear up most things.

Unlike with math operators, `ABS <String>`, `/=` or any other operator apart from adding or subtracting fulfill no other purpose than throwing errors - errors make the program skip the remaining line and jump to the next.

examples.title: Adding Strings
examples.description: The local variable 'result' will hold the value `HelloWorld`.

examples.title: Subtracting Strings
examples.description: The local variable 'result' will hold the value `HelloHelloWorld`. If you remove one String from another the program will always only delete the first occurrence of the part you're trying to remove.
The local variable 'result' will hold the value `HelloWorld`. `+=` will apply the operator immediately with the given String and add it to the selected variable.

entries.title: Loops
entries.description: Finite and infinite loops like `for` and `while`.
entries.det_desc: Unlike other languages, YOLOL doesn't come with pre-defined loops. No simple `for` or `while` - we'll have to do that ourselves with the help of if's and goto's!

examples.title: Infinite loop
examples.description: For each iteration this loop increases `i` by one - i will increase until an overflow error occurs.

examples.title: Finite loop
examples.code:
i = 0
if i < 10 goto 3 end goto 4
i++ goto 2
examples.description: For each iteration this loop compares if `i` is smaller than 10 and increases `i` by one if this is the case - `i` won't be increased above 10.

entries.title: Math operators +
entries.description: All about SIN, COS, TAN, roots and exponents.
entries.det_desc: More complex math for more complex things! With these functions you can calculate all sorts of things - Angles, distances or simply the root of 16.

examples.title: Length of hypotenuse in a right triangle
examples.code:
# a ◣ c
#     b
b = 4
alpha = 30
beta = 180 - 90 - alpha
c = b / SIN beta
examples.description: Note: A triangle only has 180 degrees in total - a right triangle always has one angle of 90 degrees. With that and the single given angle we can easily calculate the missing angle and with that calculate the hypotenuse (c).

examples.title: Factorial calculations
examples.code:
a = 3!
b = a!
c = a! + b!
examples.description: `a` will hold the result of `3 * 2 * 1 = 6`, `b` will hold the factorial of 6 (= 720) and `c` the result of 6 + 720.

examples.title: Uncovering the trooth
examples.description: `release` now holds the root that will answer all of our questions..

entries.title: Increments and decrements
entries.det_desc: An increment `++` adds 'one' to a variable. A decrement `--` removes 'one' from a variable. One in this case is dependant on the type of the variable you want to in-/ decrement - a number will be in-/ decreased by `1`, a String will be appended an empty space or removed the last character. There's also a big difference between using `++` and `--` before or after the field's name - learn more about post- and pre-increments.

examples.title: Calculating String length
examples.code:
y = "Hello World!"
y-- i++ y-- i++ y-- i++ y-- i++ y-- i++ y-- i++ y-- i++ y-- i++ goto 2
examples.description: After this code 'terminated' `i` will hold the length of given String.
